When night with moistening dews bespreads the ground,</br>And casts her sable mantle o'er the sky;</br>When fear-created spectres stalk around,</br>And through the air foreboding screech-owls cry:
Oft from the noisy sons of mirth and play,</br>By pensive thought and meditation led,</br>Hither with slow and silent steps I stray,</br>To mark the gloomy mansions of the dead.
And as I pass the lowly graves among,</br>And sculptur'd tombs of those of high-rais'd pow'r,</br>How do they tell, with awe-expressive tongue,</br>"The life of man is as the fading flow'r!"
A time he struts in mimic pride and state,</br>A time his opening blossoms are displayed;</br>But death's cold hand soon seals his certain fate—</br>And soon, alas!  upon the bier is laid.
But see!  the clouds are vanish'd with the breeze,</br>The heav'ns are fair, and Luna's paler light</br>Tips with a silver hue the drooping trees,</br>And brings each letter'd tomb-stone to my sight.
Here lies, commixed with her kindred mould,</br>A maid, who once with love each breast inspired,</br>Whose numerous virtues many a verse has told,</br>Whom all regarded, and whom all admir'd.
Ah me, her blooming period soon was o'er;</br>Scarce twenty years were number'd as her own:</br>The gazing crowd she captivates no more,</br>But ev'ry beauty, ev'ry grace is flown!
Mark this, ye thoughtless virgins of our isle;</br>Nor boast your charms, your riches, or your birth;</br>The flowery path is trod but for a while,</br>And lo, we slumber in the chilly earth!
Here moulders one, whose avaricious soul,</br>Intent on nought but usury and gain,</br>Ne'er dropt his mite into the "beggar's bowl;"</br>At whose barr'd gate distress might weep in vain.
O sordid wretch!  how useless now thy wealth,</br>Perpetual source of anxious care and strife;</br>Not all could buy that precious jewel — health,</br>Nor add one moment to thy ill-spent life.
Here lies a Bard, who once his manly page</br>With glowing precepts filled in virtue's aid;</br>But, left to perish by a thankless age,</br>His woe-worn breast the debt of nature paid.

Blush, blush, ye rich, array'd in pomp and state,</br>To think how soon his circling years were o'er;</br>Haste to save others from the like hard fate,</br>And cherish genius' sons, and wisdom's lore.
Beside this stone a tender infant sleeps;</br>Who in its cradle's bed resign'd its breath;</br>Whose early loss a feeling mother weeps,</br>And blames, (unthinking blames,) the work of death.
Ah, happy innocent, how sweet thy rest!</br>No horrid crimes are heap'd upon thy head;</br>No hurtful passions rag'd within thy breast,</br>Nor were thy shorten'd days in mis'ry led.
But say, what means this laurel-crowned bust?</br>This lofty monument?  this trophied tomb?</br>Lies here the famous chieftain, turn'd to dust?</br>And shares the warrior-prince the common doom?
What!  could not he, so valiant in the field,</br>So pow'rful, great, and terrible in fight,</br>Against the lance of fate oppose the shield,</br>And rest securely on his strength and might?
No, all the wreaths are wrested from his brow,</br>And all his boasted prowess overthrown;</br>And here he lies, as silent and as low</br>As the weak coward, or the meanest clown!
How futile now the decorated urn,</br>The costly ornaments of pride how vain!</br>Since, when once passed th' irremeable bourn,</br>Th' entombed body is but dust again.
So thought the venerable man, who long</br>Ador'd his Maker in this house of prayer;</br>Who taught his flock to raise the holy song,</br>And worship Heaven with reverend love and fear.
For see, this stone, so humble and so low,</br>Obscur'd beneath the weeping willow's shade,</br>Alone remains to let the stranger know,</br>That here Christ's faithful minister is laid.
Yet yon proud bust, that rears its head so high,</br>And stands a Statesman's honors to declare,</br>In no one breast excites a pensive sigh,</br>Altho' his grave be moist with many a tear.
For, ah!  he liv'd the poor man's constant friend,</br>And fed with fostering care the parish round;</br>His pious doctrine sooth'd the sinner's end,</br>And woe in him a kind reliever found.
Nor scorn my muse, this turf concealed clod,</br>Where rests a peasant from his daily toil,</br>Whose honest heart with rustic mirth o'erflow'd,</br>Whose part it was to turn the yielding soil.
Oft have I seen him press the useful plough,</br>And reap the harvest of his small domain;</br>Oft lay with sounding axe the forest low,</br>And beat with echoing stroke the ripen'd grain.
No hateful anger in his bosom rose,</br>No griping av'rice dwelt beneath his roof;</br>No conscious guilt disturb'd his calm repose,</br>Nor wish'd he more than nature deem'd enough.
May I like him my future moments spend!</br>May such contentment reign within this breast,</br>So shall my soul, whene'er it meets her end,</br>Partake with him of happiness and rest!</br>
